title: kotajikikox
author: kotajikikox
content: Starting this post with the disclaimer that I do know world events or political news do not completely control where the market will go. However, we can't deny that these news still have some bearing on how the market looks like. I firmly stand by the belief that even without Trump winning and promising all good there is towards bitcoin, bitcoin would still have reached $100k either way. But Trump winning did speed up the process so this is the kind of bearing I am talking about.El Salvador is one of the countries with most bitcoins and unlike other countries, A lot of the bitcoins they hold are coins they actually bought willingly and not just seized from criminal arrests. They are at the forefront of adopting bitcoin making it their legal tender and their president actively pushing for bitcoin's adoption in their country. We often talk about El Salvador in this forum and we praise all the progress they are making but the truth is they are not as nearly as influential as the USA. Can you imagine the effects if it was the US that made bitcoin as their legal tender? The reactions would be a lot bigger than the reaction of that from El Salvador.Which got me to think about the possible consequences if El Salvador were to ever announce that it is selling its bitcoins and plans to never buy any more? I am aware that the possibility of that is low since El Salvador has always expressed interest towards bitcoin but just hypothetically, how much would bitcoin be affected if El Salvador does not show support any more?

comments.author: Zeddquiver
comments.body: You have a point actually,bitcoin would have still hit 100k with Trump being the president of the US or not.Although his victory gave a huge headstart to the rise of bitcoin  to 100k.If the US had adopted bitcoin as their legal tender as El Salvador did it would have gone global and been the talk of the town making bitcoin even more famous and promoting its value amongst other nations creating a great influence and tempting other countries to do same.Moreover, speaking of how bitcoin would be affected if El Salvador stopped giving support,from my point of view bitcoin would be slightly affected but it would be at the cost of El Salvador because bitcoin has greatly  contributed to the economic growth and development of the country.I think they would not ever think of taking such drastic action because it would be a disadvantage.

Bitcoin's scarcity can guarrantee that it doesn't really matter. There will always be 21M bitcoins. And, even better if they sell, we will buy cheaper!

comments.author: Ambatman
comments.body: Selling their Bitcoin would have less direct  impact on the market but it would have a psychological impact that would lead to temporary sales. But the market will fill the gap in no time. El Salvador isn't influential, their advantage is being the forerunner of countries accepting Bitcoin and actively buying it. El Salvador needs Bitcoin more than Bitcoin needs it.

comments.author: retreat
comments.body: It is not necessary to think too much about the impact if El Salvador sells their Bitcoin - they only have 5k something Bitcoin right now, even this amount can not be said to be much. Even if they sell it and do not intend to reinvest, it will only have a small effect on the market, then the market will recover again. But what about them? They will only get a short-term profit but they miss out on the various benefits of Bitcoin adoption, so here they will be the ones who will lose, while the Bitcoin market is fine.

comments.author: icalical
comments.body: If El Savador actually sell their Bitcoin, the market confidence will definitely drop and the bitcoin price though the chance might be low, it might follow. However, because with recent Bitcoin ETF bloom and Bitcoin adoption is getting wider the market will recover in short time. While the breakthrough by El Salvador making Bitcoin as legal tender is influential, but if the US is doing the same thing, that would have a much greater effect given the nation's economic power and dominance in global financial markets.

comments.author: pooya87
comments.body: Quote from: kotajikikox on December 24, 2024, 04:07:35 AMWhich got me to think about the possible consequences if El Salvador were to ever announce that it is selling its bitcoins and plans to never buy any more? I am aware that the possibility of that is low since El Salvador has always expressed interest towards bitcoin but just hypothetically, how much would bitcoin be affected if El Salvador does not show support any more?Generally there are only 2 ways that something like this can affect the price (effect is only on price, not much else):1. By dumping on the centralized exchanges and pushing the price down.Meaning if the El Salvadorian government signs up on centralized exchanges like Coinbase, Binance, Kraken, etc. and start selling (dumping) their coins there. That way the price would directly crash because of the increased REAL sell pressure.But they'll never do such a thing. They'll sell it the same way they bought those coins, off the CEXes...2. By talking about the sale and causing the weak hands to panic sell.This is what usually happens and because we are talking about "weak hands" panicking, their collective sell pressure is not something that can be predicted.But I speculate that because this hypothetical situation is not a very significant thing, the panic sell shouldn't be that big either. And it will definitely be a short lived panic.2.1. Another important factor during panic sells would be the existing market trend. During bull runs with a strong momentum, such news would be completely ignored and we may not even see any kind of panic sell. But during a bear market or when price is going side way without knowing which direction to go, the negative effect of it is stronger.

comments.author: BlackBoss_

By dumping on the centralized exchanges and pushing the price down.They will do it through OTC market, not on CEX. OTC market is perfect place for institutional investors to purchase and sell bitcoin. Like Bitcoin Spot ETFs, they tried to accumulate bitcoin through OTC market first, not on CEX first. Because on CEX, their massive buy or sell will affect trading volume and price.CEX is their last choice if there is no other place to buy or sell, especially selling their bitcoin.Quote2. By talking about the sale and causing the weak hands to panic sell.If they do it, they will not sell all their bitcoins. That saying, if appears, will be used as a fud, to make a market crash, and help El Salvador buying dips. They can sell their bitcoins, but they will never want to make noise about it. It affects the market and money they can get from taking profit.

comments.author: PrivacyG
comments.body: Have you considered the Charts of previous Bitcoin cycles?  If you take a look, every time Bitcoin had a Halving event, it took around one year for Bitcoin to start a Bull run and hit new records.  I am surprised Bitcoin has not surpassed much higher levels yet, although it still has time for that.Therefore I do not believe Bitcoin has been too influenced by El Salvador or what Trump said about Bitcoin.  Halving is an event that happens no matter who says what and Bitcoin is pretty much unprofitable for Miners if it does not double its price in enough time.  It is a natural thing for Bitcoin and maybe there is a build up of hype around Trump, Saylor and Salvador but I do not think it influences the Price too much.In fact.  I actually think the more normalized Bitcoin becomes, the less hype there will be and people will think it truly 'dies' once and for all.  We are hyped because Bitcoin is STILL a baby and a lot of things can still happen with it.

comments.author: Haunebu
comments.body: BTC isn't dependent on Trump or any single person and history has pretty much proven that which is why I agree with your statements op. El Salvador selling their entire BTC stash would most probably have a small impact on the crypto market on the whole.Why? Because it's a small country which isn't capable of causing a huge dent to BTC price basically. If more countries followed suite though, it would lead to a crazy bear market.

comments.author: apogio
comments.body: Quote from: PrivacyG on December 24, 2024, 03:28:15 PMI am surprised Bitcoin has not surpassed much higher levels yet, although it still has time for that.I don't think you should be.Like everything in finance, the larger an asset becomes, the less volatile it gets.The inertia is part of the process and is natural, considering that Bitcoin is a huge asset already.How huge exactly? Good question, but I 'd say (completely arbitrarily) that Bitcoin is 3 - 5 times smaller than I 'd like it to be today.I 'd like Bitcoin to have gained 50% of gold's market cap already, but it's still at 10%.

comments.author: Lucius
comments.body: Quote from: kotajikikox on December 24, 2024, 04:07:35 AM~snip~Which got me to think about the possible consequences if El Salvador were to ever announce that it is selling its bitcoins and plans to never buy any more? I am aware that the possibility of that is low since El Salvador has always expressed interest towards bitcoin but just hypothetically, how much would bitcoin be affected if El Salvador does not show support any more?What is it with people today, everyone wants to be OP and they don't know that the forum has a search option? Topic opened a few days ago -> What happens to $BTC when El Salvador sells their Bitcoin?To even understand how pointless these questions are, a few facts need to be taken into account.The first is that ES has around 6000 BTC, which is a drop in the ocean compared to what is traded on a daily basis - currently CMC shows that the volume is around 550 000 BTC or around $53 billion. The second fact is that the ES is a very insignificant country in any respect, the poverty rate has increased by about 5% in recent years and today it is over 30%, people live hard, and the president calls himself the most handsome dictator who at the same time builds some kind of hospitals for pets. The third and very important fact is that Bukele will not be president forever, and whoever succeeds him may conclude that the BTC experiment has failed, sell all coins and decide on a new experiment.ES is a conveniently constructed story about a country where everyone pays with BTC and the same it's legal tender, but it's just an illusion - a poor man is still poor no matter what currency his country declares as legal tender.

comments.author: PrivacyG
comments.body: Quote from: apogio on December 24, 2024, 03:37:44 PMI don't think you should be.Like everything in finance, the larger an asset becomes, the less volatile it gets.The inertia is part of the process and is natural, considering that Bitcoin is a huge asset already.How huge exactly? Good question, but I 'd say (completely arbitrarily) that Bitcoin is 3 - 5 times smaller than I 'd like it to be today.I 'd like Bitcoin to have gained 50% of gold's market cap already, but it's still at 10%.I do not have a Bitcoin Chart at hand.  But.  As far as I know, Bitcoin cycles looked almost identical every four years.  I believe Bitcoin touched the highest point of the Bullish cliff around January to February at most.  This is why I believe there still is time for the cycle to only be repeated yet again.I do remember certainly that in the last few cycles news and Bitcoin Talk discussions always hit around Christmas about Bitcoin probably touching new highs only after New Year Eve because people had to sell Bitcoin to purchase gifts for Holidays.  So I think we are at the exact same point.  Bitcoin touched new highs just before Christmas, now Bitcoin is yet again dropping around Christmas.Does it mean Bitcoin will touch a new high during January to February?  Maybe.  It is yet to be seen.

They will only get a short-term profit but they miss out on the various benefits of Bitcoin adoption, so here they will be the ones who will lose, while the Bitcoin market is fine.El Salvador's holdings are small, compared to giants such as BlackRock and MicroStrategy. Selling it all, won't have much of an impact on market prices. Besides, the country made a deal with the IMF to wind down the "Chivo" wallet (a government-backed Bitcoin wallet) among other things. It needed the money to sustain its operations. I guess mainstream adoption will further diminish until El Salvador is back to "ground zero". I'm afraid Bitcoin becoming a national currency is only a dream. Who would think governments will surrender their power/control of money in favor of a decentralized cryptocurrency that's outside of their reach? Ultimately, CBDCs will take over the world while Bitcoin gets "left behind in the dust". It will still be functional and traded on the market, but it won't be used as a replacement for Fiat by the masses. Hopefully I'm wrong, and other countries besides El Salvador adopts BTC as their official currency. Just my two sats.
